speaker: Neil
text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English and I'm Neil. And joining me today is Rob.

speaker: Rob
text: Hello.

speaker: Neil
text: Rob, how do feel about shopping?

speaker: Rob
text: Urgh! Mooching around a shopping mall from one shop to another, spending money -  it's my idea of hell!

speaker: Neil
text: How about shopping online?

speaker: Rob
text: Ah yes, much better – sitting in front of the TV and browsing online is much easier.

speaker: Neil
text: Well that can be a problem – it's sometimes too easy, especially when we are tired – and we sometimes make purchases we regret. That's what we'll be talking about in this programme – an activity known as 'vampire shopping'.  But before we continue, it's my job to set you a quiz question, so here goes. According to the UK's Office for National Statistics, at the end of 2018, what percentage of all retail sales took place online? Was it…

speaker: Rob
text: Buying things online is big business now, so I'll say c) 29.8%.

speaker: Neil
text: Well, you’ll have to wait a bit to find out. But let's talk more now about vampire shopping – this term refers to shopping late at night - traditionally a time when vampires appear.

speaker: insomniac
text: Most of us are asleep at this time but sleep-deprived parents, shift-workers and gamers might not be. If you're an insomniac – someone who can't sleep easily – it's tempting to open up your laptop and start shopping.

speaker: Neil
text: Online shops are open 24 hours a day so it's easy to get sucked in and do some shopping!

speaker: get sucked into something
text: When you get sucked into something it means you can't stop yourself getting involved with something that you didn't want to do. So what you're saying Neil is at night, when we're very tired, we don't always think straight and can make some bad decisions.

speaker: Neil
text: That's right. And this shopping temptation can be particularly problematic for those with mental health issues. It's something Helen Undy has been talking about on the BBC Radio 4 programme, You and Yours. She is the Chief Executive of the Money and Mental Health Institute. Let's hear what she had to say…

speaker: sleep deprivedresist the urge
text: Our ability to control our impulse to spend and to resist things like advertising is reduced when we're sleep deprived. Well mental health problems can have a similar effect so the mental health problems themselves make it harder to resist the urge to spend and they also cause sleep deprivation, so  you're alone possibly surfing the internet, and both the lack of sleep and the mental health problems make it harder to resist the things that you can see.

speaker: sleep deprived resist the urge
text: Helen said that for all us, when we're sleep deprived – that means not having enough sleep – we find it harder to resist the urge to shop. We're more sucked in to shopping by the advertising we see.

speaker: resist the urge
text: And resist the urge means stop yourself acting on a strong feeling to do something. But this is more serious for people with mental health issues. They are particularly sleep deprived and along with everything that's going on in their minds, they find it harder to resist – to stop themselves buying things.

speaker: feel-good factorregret
text: I suppose buying things at night, if you're alone, gives you some comfort - even a feel-good factor – doing something that gives someone a happy and positive feeling. I certainly feel good when I've bought something. But Rob, have you ever bought something you regret?

speaker: Rob
text: Yes. Bits of tech, even flight tickets to somewhere I didn't really want to go to – because they were cheap!

speaker: Regret
text: Regret is a sad feeling you get when you've made a mistake and wished you hadn't made the mistake in the first place. We all have regrets Rob, particularly when buying things – but there's usually the option to return something and get a refund.

speaker: Rob
text: That's true but it's not always easy. Let's hear what Helen Undy had to say about that.

speaker: regretted
text: We found in our research that 75% of people, so regardless of whether you've got a mental health problem or not - three-quarters of people didn't send back the last thing they bought online that they regretted.  We found that 4 in 10 people with mental health problems didn't send things back because they were so ashamed of the things that they were buying that they just wanted to pretend it never happened.

speaker: regretted
text: So, she says that three-quarters of people didn't send back the last thing they bought that they regretted. Maybe they were too embarrassed?

speaker: Rob
text: Possibly. But it's not always easy to return an item and for those with mental health issues it can be a struggle,  a great effort. Helen Undy says that sometimes they were ashamed of their purchase.

speaker: Neil
text: Well I think we have all bought things we are ashamed of. But while online shopping continues to expand the temptation will always be there.

speaker: Rob
text: Well your question earlier was about the rise in online shopping, so what's the answer, Neil?

speaker: Neil
text: I asked according to the UK's Office for National Statistics, at the end of 2018, what percentage of all retail sales took place online? Was it…

speaker: Rob
text: I said c) 29.8%. I've got to be right!

speaker: Neil
text: Well, you're not. The rise was a bit smaller at b) 19.8%. But that's still large compared with ten years previously, when the figure was just 5.8% of all retail sales.

speaker: insomniac
text: No doubt the figure will continue to rise. And before I nip off to do a bit of vampire shopping, let's recap some of the vocabulary we've mentioned today. Starting with insomniac.

speaker: insomniacinsomnia
text: An insomniac is someone who can't sleep easily. They suffer from insomnia.

speaker: toget sucked into something.
text: Next we talked about to get sucked into something. This informal phrase means not being able to stop yourself getting involved with something that you don't want to do.

speaker: sleep deprived
text: If you are sleep deprived, you do not having enough sleep.

speaker: resist the urge
text: And if you resist the urge, you stop yourself acting on a strong feeling to do something. For example, resisting the urge to buy something online.

speaker: feel-good factor.  feel-good factor
text: But if you don't resist the urge to buy something, it might have a feel-good factor. A feel-good factor is something that makes you feel happy and positive.

speaker: regret.
text: But after buying something you may have regret. That's a sad feeling you get when you've made a mistake and wished you hadn't made the mistake in the first place.

speaker: Neil
text: Well hopefully you haven't regretted spending 6 minutes listening to us!  Please join us next time and in the meantime, why not check us out on your favourite social media platforms and on our app.

speaker: Rob
text: Goodbye!

speaker: Neil
text: Goodbye!
